content.user_title: Set up analytics tracking and measurement
content.value_statement: Analytics tracking setup is complex and error-prone, leading to unreliable data. This skill provides expert guidance for implementing GA4, GTM, conversion tracking, and UTM strategies that deliver actionable insights for marketing and product decisions.
actual_capabilities: Create comprehensive tracking plans aligned with business decisions
Design event naming conventions and property structures for GA4 and GTM
Implement conversion tracking with proper event configuration
Build UTM parameter strategies for campaign attribution
Debug and validate analytics implementations using GA4 DebugView and GTM Preview
Configure privacy-compliant tracking with GA4 Consent Mode
limitations: Does not modify or deploy code to user systems
Cannot access user analytics accounts or credentials
Does not provide real-time data analysis or reporting
Cannot install or configure browser extensions or tag containers

use_cases.title: Create tracking plan for new product launch
use_cases.description: Marketing teams can use this skill to design a comprehensive tracking plan that captures key user actions, conversion events, and campaign attribution before launching a new product or feature.

use_cases.title: Audit existing GA4 implementation
use_cases.description: Data teams can use this skill to review current tracking setups, identify gaps in event coverage, validate naming conventions, and ensure data quality across web and mobile properties.

use_cases.title: Set up conversion tracking for paid campaigns
use_cases.description: Performance marketers can use this skill to implement proper conversion tracking for Google Ads and other paid channels, including UTM parameter conventions and GA4 conversion imports.

prompt_templates.title: Basic tracking setup
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to set up analytics tracking for my [website/product]. What are the essential events I should track for [business goal]? Provide a tracking plan template with event names, properties, and triggers.

prompt_templates.title: GA4 event configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure [specific event] in GA4 using gtag.js? Show me the code snippet and explain how to mark it as a conversion. Also explain the difference between once-per-session and every-time counting.

prompt_templates.title: GTM container structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me organize my Google Tag Manager container for [website type]. What tags, triggers, and variables should I set up for proper GA4 event tracking? Include naming conventions and folder structure recommendations.

prompt_templates.title: Campaign attribution with UTM parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a UTM parameter naming convention for my [campaign type] campaigns. Include examples for source, medium, campaign, content, and term parameters. Also provide a documentation template for tracking all campaign URLs.

output_examples.input: I want to track key actions for my SaaS product. What events should I set up?
output_examples.output:
## Essential Events for SaaS Product

### Core Conversion Events
- `signup_started` - User initiates signup (source, page)
- `signup_completed` - User completes signup (method, plan)
- `onboarding_completed` - User finishes onboarding flow

### Feature Engagement
- `feature_used` - User uses specific feature (feature_name)
- `action_completed` - Core action completed (action_type)

### Monetization
- `trial_started` - Free trial initiated
- `checkout_started` - User begins checkout
- `purchase_completed` - Purchase finished (plan, value, currency)

### Engagement Metrics
- `session_started` - New session begins
- `session_ended` - Session ends (session_duration)
- `key_action_completed` - First-time key action (milestone)

output_examples.input: How do I set up UTM parameters for my email campaigns?
output_examples.output:
## UTM Parameter Convention for Email Campaigns

| Parameter | Value | Example |
|-----------|-------|---------|
| utm_source | newsletter | utm_source=newsletter |
| utm_medium | email | utm_medium=email |
| utm_campaign | monthly_newsletter_january | utm_campaign=monthly_newsletter_january |
| utm_content | hero_cta_button | utm_content=hero_cta_button |

### Example URL
```
https://yoursite.com/pricing?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=monthly_newsletter_january&utm_content=hero_cta_button
```

### Best Practices
- Use lowercase for all parameters
- Use underscores or hyphens consistently
- Include campaign date for tracking over time
- Document all UTMs in a spreadsheet for reference

output_examples.input: Validate my GA4 event tracking implementation
output_examples.output:
## Validation Checklist

### Pre-Launch
- [ ] Events fire on correct triggers
- [ ] Property values populate correctly
- [ ] No duplicate events firing
- [ ] User ID passes when logged in
- [ ] No PII in event properties

### Testing Tools
- **GA4 DebugView**: Add ?debug_mode=true to URL
- **GTM Preview Mode**: Test triggers before publishing
- **Chrome Extensions**: GA Debugger, Tag Assistant

### Common Issues to Check
- Trigger firing before data layer is ready
- Multiple GTM containers causing duplicates
- Events firing on wrong pages
- Custom dimensions not matching parameter names

best_practices: Start with business questions, then work backwards to determine what to track. Avoid collecting data for its own sake.
Use consistent naming conventions (lowercase with underscores) and document all decisions in a tracking plan.
Validate implementations using GA4 DebugView and GTM Preview mode before going live. Test across browsers and devices.
anti_patterns: Tracking everything without a clear decision or action tied to each event. Quality matters more than quantity.
Including dynamic values like user IDs, email addresses, or prices directly in event names. Use properties instead.
Setting up tracking without documentation. Without a tracking plan, teams cannot maintain consistency or audit implementations.

faq.question: What is the difference between GA4 standard events and custom events?
faq.answer: Standard events are predefined by Google with specific naming and parameters (like purchase, sign_up, login). They enable enhanced reporting features. Custom events are any events you define yourself. Use standard events when available for better analytics, and custom events for tracking specific business actions not covered by standard events.

faq.question: How do I track events across web and mobile apps in GA4?
faq.answer: Set up separate data streams for web and iOS/Android in GA4. Use the same event names across platforms for consistency. For mobile, implement Firebase SDK which sends data to GA4. Configure user properties to identify the same user across devices if applicable.

faq.question: What are enhanced measurement events in GA4?
faq.answer: Enhanced measurement automatically tracks page views, scroll depth (90%), outbound clicks, site searches, video engagement, and file downloads. These are enabled by default on data streams. Review and adjust which events are tracked based on your privacy requirements and data needs.

faq.question: How do I prevent PII from being tracked in analytics?
faq.answer: Never send email addresses, names, phone numbers, or other directly identifying information in event parameters. Use user_id (a hash or pseudonymized identifier) instead. Implement GA4 Consent Mode to handle cookie consent requirements. Enable IP anonymization in GA4 settings.

faq.question: What is the difference between GTM and gtag.js for GA4?
faq.answer: Gtag.js is a simple tagging script directly on pages. Google Tag Manager is a tag management system that lets you configure and deploy tags without modifying site code. GTM provides more flexibility for complex implementations, multiple tags, and team collaboration. For most implementations, GTM is recommended.

faq.question: How often should I review and audit my analytics tracking?
faq.answer: Review tracking quarterly to ensure events still align with business goals. Audit after major site changes, new feature launches, or when data quality issues arise. Regular validation using DebugView and monitoring for duplicate events helps maintain data integrity over time.
